On Thu, 07 Oct 2004 13:14:08 -0000, Bryan Adams <bpadams@...> wrote:
> My question, then, is this: how do you set the parameters that govern
> the NEAT system? 

That's the $64,000 question, isn't it? :)

You say you'll give bonus stars for non-ad-hoc approaches, but as far
as I know, that's the way most people tune their algorithm.  I'm
guessing that a mixture of intuition, experience, and tinkering were
how Ken arrived at many of the parameter settings he recommends for
various domains...though if he had a more concrete approach, I'd
certainly like to hear it too.

I've heard people toss around the idea of making such parameters
subject to mutation as well, but I haven't seen it really implemented,
and I'm not sure it'd be such a great idea.
 
> What, aside from a solution, are
> the variables to look for when evaluating the quality of a run?

Well, we've experimented in game domains and now image recognition,
and well before a network in our population finds a solution, what
we're looking at are the min, max, and mean fitness for each
generation.  We're looking for an increase in each of those
indicators.  In fact, even if the max fitness is not increasing, but
the mean is, that's usually a good sign, since the overall population
is improving, and we'll usually subsequently see improvement in max
fitness.  What we *don't* want is flatness in all three, for many
generations.

We also look at the variability in fitness between generations.  If
the max fitness is fluctuating wildly (e.g., between 50% and 90% max
fitness each generation), then our evaluation is probably too noisy.

Other factors we try to keep tabs on have to do with population and
speciation dynamics.  We generally want to see a split of the
population into several different species relatively early in the run,
because we want to be exploring different parts of the solution space.
 We also want to monitor turnover in the population, make sure that
species that aren't holding their own go extinct, that new species
arise, and that new champions take the place of old ones.

We use SVG-based visualization tools to monitor this stuff:

http://nevt.sourceforge.net/

Though the speciation visualization doesn't really capture the
information we want very well.  If you generate data in an XML format
similar to what we and Colin use, you can use these tools.  Or you can
build your own visualization stuff...either way, I think it's
important to have visualization of important features to track
progress during runs, and to do post-run analysis.

Derek
